holidays.name: National Puzzle Day
holidays.description: A day to embrace the love of puzzles ‚Äî whether jigsaw, crossword, sudoku, or brain teasers! It‚Äôs all about challenging your mind and having fun with problem-solving.
holidays.origin: Created in 2002 by Jodi Jill, a puzzle enthusiast who wanted to celebrate the joy and benefits of puzzles.
holidays.funFact: Studies show that regularly doing puzzles can actually help delay cognitive decline as we age!

holidays.name: Cornchip Day
holidays.description: A quirky food holiday celebrating the humble corn chip ‚Äî those crunchy, salty snacks that make any dip more delicious.
holidays.origin: Not officially declared by any major organization; likely started by snack lovers and food bloggers.
holidays.funFact: The first corn chips were popularized in the 1930s by the Fritos brand, making them a tasty American snack staple.

holidays.name: Blame Someone Else Day
holidays.description: A funny, unofficial holiday where you get to shift the blame for something ‚Äî just for fun! It‚Äôs all about lighthearted scapegoating and having a laugh.
holidays.origin: Thought to have started in the 1980s as a tongue-in-cheek response to everyday frustrations, encouraging humor rather than actual blame.
holidays.funFact: On this day, people jokingly blame everything from spilled coffee to missed appointments on imaginary culprits ‚Äî even their pets!

holidays.name: Data Privacy Day (International)
holidays.description: A day to raise awareness about the importance of protecting personal information and digital privacy in the age of the internet.
holidays.origin: Originated in Europe in 2007 as Data Protection Day, marking the Jan 28, 1981 signing of Convention 108, but observed internationally on Jan 28-29.
holidays.funFact: Organizations use this day to launch new privacy tools and educate users about keeping their data safe online.
